revisions.rev:
{{Infobox pipeline | name = Arab Gas Pipeline | type = natural gas | map = Arab_Gas_Pipeline.svg | map_caption = Location of Arab Gas Pipeline | country = [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]], [[Syria]], [[Lebanon]], [[Turkey]] | coordinates = | photo = | caption = | operator = | partners = [[EGAS]]
[[ENPPI]]
[[PETROGET]]
[[Egyptian Natural Gas Company|GASCO]]
[[Syrian Petroleum Company|SPC]] | length_km = 1200 | discharge = {{convert|10.3|e9m3}} | direction = south-north | start = [[Arish]] | finish = [[Homs]], [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]], ([[Kilis]]) | est = 2011 | through = [[Aqaba]], [[Amman]], [[El Rehab]], [[Deir Ali]], [[Damascus]], [[Baniyas]], [[Aleppo]] | par = }} The '''Arab Gas Pipeline''' is a [[natural gas]] pipeline in the [[Middle East]]. It exports [[Egypt]]ian natural gas to [[Jordan]], [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]], with a separate line to [[Israel]]. It has a total length of {{convert|1200|km}} at a cost of [[US$]]1.2 billion. {{cite news |url= http://yalibnan.com/site/archives/2008/02/_the_meeting_co.php |title=Lebanon minister in Syria to discuss the Arab Gas Pipeline |publisher=Ya Libnan |date=2008-02-23 |accessdate=2008-03-10 }} ==Description== ===ArishâAqaba section=== The first section of pipeline runs from [[Arish]] in Egypt to [[Aqaba]] in Jordan. It has three segments. The first {{convert|250|km|mi}} long overland segment links Al-Arish to [[Taba (Egypt)|Taba]] on the [[Red Sea]]. It also consists of a compressor station in Arish and a metering station in Taba. The second segment is a {{convert|15|km|mi}} long subsea segment from Taba to Aqaba. The third segment, which includes also a metering station, is a {{convert|1|km|mi}} long onshore connection to the [[Aqaba Thermal Power Station]]. {{cite web | publisher= The Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development | url= http://www.arabfund.org/Project/proj427.htm | title = Natural Gas Pipeline (Al-Arish â Aqaba). Project fact sheet | accessdate=2008-08-12 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080405225434/http://www.arabfund.org/Project/proj427.htm |archivedate = 2008-04-05}} The $220 million ArishâAqaba section was completed in July 2003. {{cite news | publisher= Gulf Oil & Gas | url= http://www.gulfoilandgas.com/webpro1/MAIN/Mainnews.asp?id=357 | title = Arab gas pipeline agreement | date = 2004-01-26 | accessdate=2007-10-05}} The diameter of the pipeline is {{convert|36|in|mm|-1}} and has a capacity of {{convert|10.3|e9m3|abbr=off}} of natural gas per year. {{cite news | publisher= Oil and Gas Insight | url= http://www.stroytransgaz.com/press-center/smi/bmi-industry-insights-/04092009 | title = Arab Gas Pipeline Primes Lebanon Branch | date = 2009-09-04 | accessdate=2009-10-24}} The Egyptian consortium that developed this section included [[EGAS]], [[ENPPI]], [[PETROGET]] and the [[Egyptian Natural Gas Company|Egyptian Natural Gas Company (GASCO)]]. === AqabaâEl Rehab section === The second section extended the pipeline in Jordan from Aqaba through [[Amman]] to [[El Rehab]], ({{convert|24|km}} from the Syrian border). The length of this section is {{convert|390|km|mi}} and it cost $300 million. The second section was commissioned in 2005. ===El RehabâHoms section=== The third section has a total length of {{convert|319|km|mi}} from Jordan to Syria. A {{convert|90|km|mi}} stretch runs from the JordanâSyrian border to the [[Deir Ali]] power station. From there the pipeline runs through [[Damascus]] to the [[Al Rayan]] gas compressor station near [[Homs]]. This sections includes four launching/receiving stations, 12 valve stations and a fiscal metering station with a capacity of {{convert|1.1|e9m3|abbr=off}}, and it supplies [[Tishreen]] and Deir Ali power stations. The section was completed in February 2008, and it was built by the [[Syrian Petroleum Company]] and [[Stroytransgaz]], a subsidiary of [[Gazprom]]. {{cite news |url= http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=8761 |title=Syria Completes First Stage of Arab Gas Pipeline |agency = [[Xinhua News Agency]] |publisher=Downstream Today |date=2008-02-18 |accessdate=2008-02-23 }} {{cite web | publisher= The Canadian Trade Commissioner Service | url= http://www.infoexport.gc.ca/ie-en/DisplayDocument.jsp?did=60298#6 | title = Stroitransgaz wins tender to build the third part of Arab gas pipeline | date = November 2005 | accessdate=2008-01-14}} ===HomsâTripoli connection=== The HomsâTripoli connection runs from the Al Rayan compressor station to [[Baniyas]] in Syria and then via {{convert|32|km|adj=on}} long stretch to [[Tripoli, Lebanon]]. The agreement to start supplies was signed on 2 September 2009 and test run started on 8 September 2009. Regular gas supplies started on 19 October 2009 and gas is delivered to the [[Deir Ammar power station]]. {{cite news | publisher= Downstream Today | url= http://downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=18758 | agency = [[The McClatchy Company|McClatchy-Tribune Information Services]] | title = Lebanon Receives Egypt Gas To Run Power Plant | date = 2009-10-20 | accessdate=2009-10-24}} There is a proposal to prolong the branch from Banias to [[Cyprus]]. {{cite news | publisher= ArabicNews.com | url= http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/040925/2004092520.html | title = Timetable for extending Arab gas pipelines inside Jordan and Syria discussed | date = 2004-09-25 | accessdate=2007-10-05}} ==ArishâAshkelon pipeline== The Arishâ[[Ashkelon]] pipeline is a {{convert|100|km}} submarine gas pipeline connecting the Arab Gas Pipeline with Israel. Although it is not officially a part of the Arab Gas Pipeline project, it branches off from the same pipeline in Egypt. The pipeline is built and operated by the [[East Mediterranean Gas Company]] (EMG), a joint company of Mediterranean Gas Pipeline Ltd (28%), the Israeli company [[Merhav]] (25%), [[PTT Public Company Limited|PTT]] (25%), EMI-EGI LP (12%), and [[Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation]] (10%). {{cite news |publisher=[[PennWell Corporation]] |work=Oil & Gas Journal |url= http://www.pennenergy.com/index/petroleum/display/314171/articles/oil-gas-journal/finance-companies/ptt-buys-25-of-east-mediterranean-gas-co.html |title=PTT buys 25% of East Mediterranean Gas Co. |date=2007-12-07 |accessdate=2011-02-05}} The pipeline became operational in February 2008, at a cost of $180 million â $550 million (the exact figure is disputed).{{cite news|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000686557&fid=1725|title=IEC may seek partial ownership of Egyptian pipeline|publisher=[[Globes]]|author=Barkat, Amiram|date=September 27, 2011|accessdate=October 2, 2011}} Initially Egypt and Israel had agreed to supply through this pipeline {{convert|1.7|e9m3|abbr=off}} of natural gas per year for use by the [[Israel Electric Corporation]]. {{cite news |newspaper=[[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] |publisher=NHST Media Group |first=Nassir | last = Shirkani |url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article150348.ece |title=Egyptian gas flows to Israel |date=2008-03-10 |accessdate=2008-03-10 |id = {{subscription required}}}} This has since been raised to {{convert|2.1|e9m3|abbr=off}} per year to be delivered through the year 2028. In addition, by late 2009, EMG had signed contracts to supply through the pipeline additional {{convert|2|e9m3|abbr=off}} per year to private electricity generators and various industrial concerns in Israel and negotiations with other potential buyers were ongoing. In 2010, the pipeline is supplying approximately half of the natural gas consumed in Israel, with the other half being supplied from domestic resources. The total physical capacity of the pipeline is {{convert|9|e9m3|abbr=off}} per year and agreements between the two nations provide a framework for the purchase of up to {{convert|7.5|e9m3|abbr=off}} per year of Egyptian gas by Israeli entities, making Israel one of Egypt's most important natural gas export markets. In 2010 some Egyptian activists appealed for a legal provision against governmental authorities to stop gas flow to Israel according to the obscure contract and very low price compared to the global rates, however the provision was denied by Mubarak regime for unknown reasons. In 2011, after the 25 January Revolution against Mubarak regime, many Egyptians called for stopping the gas project with Israel due to low prices and Israeli violence against Palestinian people.{{cn|date=September 2011}} After a fifth bombing of the pipeline, flow had to be stopped for repair. {{cite news |title=Egypt's Dilemma After Israel Attacks |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/egypts-hamas-dilemma-after-attacks-in-israel-2011-8 |accessdate=20 August 2011 |newspaper=[[Business Insider]] |date=19 August 2011 |agency=[[Stratfor]] |quote=Such groups, whose ability to operate in this area depends heavily on cooperation from local Bedouins, have been suspected of responsibility for attacks on police stations and patrols as well as most if not all of five recent successful attacks on the El Arish natural gas pipeline that runs from Egypt to Israel.}} {{cite news |title=Seventeen killed in Israel attacks |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/9ea41cf0-c986-11e0-9eb8-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1VWDOVv6G |accessdate=20 August 2011 |newspaper=[[Financial Times]] |date=18 August 2011 |first1=Tobias |last1=Buck |first2=Heba |last2=Saleh |location=[[Jerusalem]], [[Cairo]] |quote= In the past six months, suspected Islamist militants in the Sinai have blown up a pipeline carrying natural gas to Israel five times.}} ==Future extensions== ===SyriaâTurkey connection=== In March 2006, Egypt, Syria, Jordan, [[Turkey]], Lebanon and [[Romania]] reached an agreement to build the pipeline's extension through Syria to the Turkish border. From there, the pipeline will be connected to the possible [[Nabucco Pipeline]] for the delivery of gas to Europe. Turkey expects to buy up to {{convert|4|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas per year from the Arab Gas Pipeline. {{cite news | publisher= Alexander's Gas & Oil Connections | url= http://www.gasandoil.com/GOC/news/nte61633.htm | title = Ministers agree to extend Arab gas pipeline to Turkey | date = 2006-03-29 | accessdate=2007-10-05}} On 4 January 2008, Turkey and Syria signed an agreement to construct a {{convert|63|km|mi}} pipeline between [[Aleppo]] and [[Kilis]] as a first segment of the Syria-Turkey connection of the Arab Gas Pipeline. {{cite news | publisher= Downstream Today | url= http://www.downstreamtoday.com/news/article.aspx?a_id=8021 | title = Syria to Buy Iranian Gas Via Turkey | work = [[Syria Times]], [[BBC News|BBC Monitoring]] | date = 2008-01-09 | accessdate=2008-01-14}} {{cite paper | publisher= Euro-Arab Mashreq Gas Co-operation Centre | url= http://eamgcc.org/archive/docs/File/downloads/EAMGCC%20newsletter%20November%202007.pdf | title = The EuroâArab Mashreq Gas Market Project â Progress November 2007 | format = PDF | accessdate=2008-01-14}} On 14 October 2008, Stroytransgaz signed a US$71 million contract for the construction of this section. {{cite news | newspaper= Kommersant | url= http://kommersant.com/p-13396/pipeline_construction/ | title = Russians Build Turkey-Syria Pipeline | date = 2008-10-14 | accessdate=2008-10-26}} This contract was annulled at the beginning of 2009 and it was re-tendered. The connection is expected to be ready by 2011. From Kilis, a {{convert|15|km|adj=on}} long pipeline with a diameter of {{convert|12|in|mm}} will connect the pipeline with the Turkish grid. It allows to supply the Turkish grid via the Syrian grid even before completing the HomsâAllepo segment. === Connection with Iraq === In September 2004, Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon agreed to connect the Arab Gas Pipeline with [[Iraq]]'s gas grid to allow Iraq to export gas to Europe. {{cite news | publisher= Gulf Oil & Gas | url= http://www.gulfoilandgas.com/webpro1/main/mainnews.asp?id=875 | title = Iraq Joins the Arab Gas Pipeline Project | date = 2004-09-26 | accessdate=2007-10-05}} == 2011 explosions == On 5 February, amidst the [[2011 Egyptian protests]] an explosion was reported at the pipeline near the El Arish natural gas compressor station, which supplies pipelines to Israel and Jordan. {{cite news | agency = [[Associated Press]] | url= http://www.latimes.com/business/nationworld/wire/sns-ap-ml--egypt-pipelineexplosion,0,2643782.story | title = Egypt TV reports explosion, fire at gas pipeline in northern Sinai Peninsula near Gaza Strip | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | first1 = Ashraf | last1 = Sweilam | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05}} {{cite news | agency = [[Reuters]] | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/egypt-idUKLDE71400820110205?sp=true | title = Leaders inside, outside Egypt seek exit from impasse | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05 | first=Edmund | last=Blair}} {{cite news | newspaper = [[Haaretz]] | url= http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/saboteurs-blow-up-egypt-israel-gas-pipeline-in-northern-sinai-1.341368 | title = Egypt holds gas supply to Israel and Jordan after pipeline explosion | first1 = Avi | last1 = Issacharoff | first2 = Barak | last2 = Ravid | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05}} {{cite news | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-05/egypt-gas-pipeline-feeding-israel-explodes-in-sinai-desert-arabiya-says.html | title = Egypt Gas Exports to Israel, Jordan Halted After Sinai Pipeline Explosion | first1 = Nayla | last1 = Razzouk | first2 = Ola | last2 = Galal | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05}} {{cite news | agency = [[CNN]] | url= http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.pipeline/?hpt=T2 | title = Gas pipeline to Jordan, Syria set ablaze in Egypt | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05}} As a result, supplies to Israel and Jordan were halted. {{cite news | agency = [[Reuters]] | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/egypt-gas-idUKLDE71406620110205?sp=true | title = Egypt gas pipeline attacked; Israel, Jordan flow hit | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05}} According to the governor of the [[North Sinai Governorate]], "a gas station located near the blast site was not damaged and the explosion has not hit the residential areas". {{cite news | agency = IANS/RIA Novosti | url= http://www.sify.com/news/blast-at-egypt-gas-pipeline-news-international-lcfsomghedi.html | title = Blast at Egypt gas pipeline | date = 2011-02-05 | publisher = [[Sify.com]] | accessdate=2011-02-05}} State television laid the blame on perpetrators "who took advantage of the unstable security situation in the country." However, according to the head of [[Egyptian Natural Gas Company]], the explosion was caused by a gas leak and not by an attack. {{cite news | agency = [[Sky News]] | url= http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Israel-Gas-Pipeline-Explosion-Reports-Of-Blast-In-North-Sinai---Terrorists-Blamed-By-State-TV/Article/201102115923569 | title = Gas Leak Explosion At Egypt-Israel Facility | first1 = Sam | last1 = Kiley | date = 2011-02-05 | accessdate=2011-02-05}} On 27 April 2011, an explosion at the pipeline near Al-Sabil village in the [[El-Arish]] region halted natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan. {{cite news | newspaper = [[Financial Times]] | url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/62b270c4-70e0-11e0-9b1d-00144feabdc0.html | title = Gunmen attack Egyptian gas terminal | first1 = Heba | last1 = Saleh | first2 = Vita | last2 = Bekker | date = 2011-04-27 | accessdate=2011-04-27}} According to the [[Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources]] unidentified saboteurs blew up a monitoring room of the pipeline. {{cite news | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-27/blast-hits-egypt-israel-gas-pipeline-forcing-supply-halt-ministry-says.html | title = Blast Hits Egypt-Israel Gas Pipeline, Forcing Supply Halt, Ministry Says | first1 = Nayla | last1 = Razzouk | first2 = Ola | last2 = Galal | first3 =Alaa | last3 = Shahine | date = 2011-04-27 | accessdate=2011-04-27}} On 4 July 2011, an explosion at the pipeline near [[Nagah]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] halted natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan. An official said that armed men with machine guns forced guards at the station to leave before planting explosive charge there. This is the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since an uprising overthrew Hosni Mubarak. There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March. {{cite news | agency = [[Al Jazeera]] | url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 2011-07-04 | accessdate=2011-07-04}} An overnight explosion on 26â27 September caused extensive damage to the pipeline at a location 50 kilometers from Egypt's border with Israel. As the pipeline had not been supplying gas to Israel since an earlier explosion in July, it did not affect Israel's natural gas supply. According to Egyptian authorities, local Bedouin Islamists were behind the attack.{{cite news|title=6th attack on Sinai gas pipeline|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000686395|accessdate=27 September 2011|newspaper=[[Globes]]|date=27 September 2011}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} [[Category:2011 establishments]] [[Category:Economy of the Arab League]] [[Category:Natural gas pipelines in Asia]] [[Category:Natural gas pipelines in Africa]] [[Category:Energy in Egypt]] [[Category:Energy in Jordan]] [[Category:Energy in Lebanon]] [[Category:Energy in Syria]] [[Category:Oil and gas pipelines in Turkey]] [[ar:Ø®Ø· Ø§ÙØºØ§Ø² Ø§ÙØ¹Ø±Ø¨Ù]] [[cs:ArabskÃ½ plynovod]] [[it:Arab Gas Pipeline]] [[he:×¦×× ××¨ ××× ××¢×¨××]] [[th:à¸à¹à¸­à¸ªà¹à¸à¹à¸à¹à¸ªà¸­à¸²à¸«à¸£à¸±à¸]] [[tr:Arap Boru HattÄ±]] [[uk:ÐÑÐ°Ð±ÑÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ Ð³Ð°Ð·Ð¾Ð¿ÑÐ¾Ð²ÑÐ´]]
